title: EMB MONDAY 'Tough' UK households can take higher interest rates, says Moody's
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Jul 27, 2015, 06:23 BST - UK Markets open in 1 hr 37 mins EMB MONDAY 'Tough' UK households can take higher interest rates, says Moody's By Andrew Trotman | Telegraph – 22 minutes ago Print 
Credit ratings agency says UK has been 'toughened up' by the financial crisis and can cope with higher mortgage payments 
UK households can withstand a rise in interest rates as they have been "toughened up" by the financial crisis, according to a new report. 
With the Bank of England just months away from increasing rates for the first time in nine years to tackle inflationary pressures, some experts fear that mortgage holders could struggle to meet higher repayments. 
However, people are "very unlikely" to slip into arrears on their mortgages as they will reduce their spending on other items to compensate for the change, credit rating agency Moody's said. 
“Borrowers that are up-to-date on their payments will be able to adjust their discretionary spending if incremental rate rises are spread out over the next three years,” states Emily Rombeau, an analyst at Moody’s and co-author of the report. 
Moody's expects the Bank to gradually start raising interest rates from their historic low of 0.5pc to around 1pc by the middle of next year. 
It believes that just 1pc of borrowers would be unable to afford their mortage payments and meet their living expenses if rates were to rise by one percentage point (pp) - double the hike it expects. 
"Even if the bank were to raise the base rate by 3pp, only 4pc more borrowers would face payment problems, a marginal proportion," Moody's stated. 
The Bank needs to act to counter inflationary pressures, the agency claimed, but Britons will cope by drawing on their experience of the financial crisis in 2007-08, which resulted in the loss of millions of jobs across the developed world and the introduction of austerity measures to cope with high government debt levels. 
“Rates would need to rise to stave-off inflationary pressure, yet arrears in residential mortgage deals are not likely to increase by much, if at all," Ms Rombeau added. 
"Rough economic conditions during the crisis have toughened up borrowers, and our outlook on [mortgage] performance remains positive in light of current favourable economic conditions [higher GDP growth and low levels of unemployment].” 
Moody's also pointed to "higher borrower credit quality" and "stronger affordability profile" as further factors that will ease UK households into higher interest rates. 
In addition, 80pc of mortgage loans granted in 2014 and the first quarter of 2015 were fixed-rate, which will protect borrowers from immediate shocks. 
However, some experts remain concerned that a rise in rates will cause chaos for mortgage holders. 
Russel Quirk, founder of estate agent emoov , said: "Over the past five or six years we have become falsely conditioned to extremely low rates. It's almost become the new normal. The reality is it isn't normal. 
"If rates increase as inflation increases, a lot of people are in for a shock. 
"Even if you're on a fixed-rate mortgage, when you come off that rate, the step from what you are used to to the new environment will be a shock." 
Simon Tyler, of broker Tyler Mortgage Management , said: “Wages have barely been rising for years but many people have stretched to get on the housing ladder, often only with the aid of government assistance. These people may find a rate hike hard to cope with."
